claim: The working hours of Americans have increased over time.

supporting.text: Data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees have remained stable or slightly decreased since the 1980s.

attacks.text: Data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees have remained stable or slightly decreased since the 1980s.
The data only covers full-time employees and excludes part-time and gig workers, whose numbers have grown significantly since the 1980s.
Even among full-time employees, unpaid overtime and off-the-clock work have increased, which may not be fully captured in official statistics.
The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics is a reliable source with rigorous methodology for tracking working hours.

supporting.text: Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for long working hours in many industries, leading to more efficient work processes.

attacks.text: Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for long working hours in many industries, leading to more efficient work processes.
Despite automation, many workers now face increased workloads due to higher productivity expectations and constant connectivity.
Studies show that automation often leads to job displacement rather than reduced hours, forcing workers to take on multiple jobs.
The gig economy and remote work have blurred the line between work and personal time, effectively increasing working hours.
Surveys indicate that remote workers often work longer hours due to lack of clear boundaries between work and home life.

supporting.text: The rise of remote work and flexible schedules has allowed many Americans to better balance work and personal life, reducing overall working hours.

attacks.text: The rise of remote work and flexible schedules has allowed many Americans to better balance work and personal life, reducing overall working hours.
Studies show that remote workers often work longer hours due to blurred boundaries between work and personal life.
Employers increasingly track productivity digitally, leading to higher expectations and longer work hours for remote employees.
Flexible schedules can lead to irregular work patterns, sometimes resulting in more hours worked to meet deadlines.
Workers with flexible schedules often compensate for perceived flexibility by working additional hours to demonstrate commitment.
Many industries still enforce traditional long-hour work cultures, unaffected by remote work trends.

supporting.text: Labor laws and workplace regulations, such as the Fair Labor Standards Act, have historically limited excessive working hours and overtime.

attacks.text: Labor laws and workplace regulations, such as the Fair Labor Standards Act, have historically limited excessive working hours and overtime.
Despite labor laws, many Americans work multiple jobs or unpaid overtime due to economic pressures, leading to increased total working hours.
The rise of the gig economy and contract work often bypasses traditional labor protections, resulting in longer and less regulated working hours.
Studies show that salaried employees, especially in high-pressure industries, frequently work beyond standard hours without additional compensation.

supporting.text: Studies indicate that part-time employment has grown as a share of total employment, which would lower the average working hours across the workforce.

attacks.text: Studies indicate that part-time employment has grown as a share of total employment, which would lower the average working hours across the workforce.
The growth in part-time employment may be offset by an increase in working hours for full-time employees, keeping the overall average stable or even increasing it.
Data shows that full-time employees are also working longer hours due to factors like remote work and gig economy pressures.
Part-time employment growth is concentrated in low-hour sectors, while high-hour sectors have seen little change, making the overall impact on average hours minimal.

supporting.text: Economic research suggests that productivity gains over time have reduced the necessity for extended working hours to maintain or increase output.

attacks.text: Economic research suggests that productivity gains over time have reduced the necessity for extended working hours to maintain or increase output.
Despite productivity gains, many industries have not reduced working hours due to competitive pressures and corporate profit motives.
Studies show that in sectors like tech and finance, working hours have actually increased despite higher productivity, as employees are expected to do more with the same time.
Productivity gains are unevenly distributed, with some workers benefiting from reduced hours while others face stagnant or increased workloads.
Government policies and labor unions in some countries have successfully translated productivity gains into shorter workweeks, but this is less common in the U.S.
